title: How to write an invitation letter to someone to invite him to attend my thesis proposal presentation - Quora

response.answer_text: The Basic Elements of InvitationsA. The name of the hosts, usually first and last names.B. The nature of the occasion.C. The time and date of the event.D. The location of the event.E. On written invitations.F. Optional a Regret only with phone number or email address. OK, now we have the basic formula Here we go.                                                                                                    October 5, 2015Dear Abe,      My thesis on "The Happiness of Life" is completed. Susan Smith and I along with Professor Nathan B. Forrest would like for you to attend my presentation. I would feel so honored to share this important part of my life with you, my friend.     The event will held on November 15, 2015 at 2:00 pm in the American Hall Room on campus. The location is 1776 Robert Lee Boulevard.     Yours truly,                              Stonewall Jackson                                                                                Regret only: 123-456-7890                                           (Or use email not both)               :Stonewall@emailDo write in paragraphs for. Depending where the letter is going mail in a timely fashion (early) 30 days before event or 15 days If this a BFF you can be witty but not funny.If for points towards a job future/placement be professional. Address the envelope properly. google how to address an envelopeBuy the book:  Emily Post Etiquette. It's a must have book in ever household.Congratulations on you thesis!

I'm assuming you are asking an academic or other researcher. I am also assuming you are not asking the person to be a formal member on your committee. A template: [Name and Address] Dear Prof. [or Dr.] XXX: I would be honored if you could attend the presentation of my thesis proposal "[Title of Proposal]" being presented on [Date and Time] at [Location]. The work being proposed concerns [brief description of topic -- 1 or 2 sentences]. [If this person might not know you, then you need to identify yourself, with something such as "I am a PhD student in Informatics at University of New Jersey working on homophone mapping under Prof. Sally Suh."] Your attendance at my proposal would be most welcome because [why do you want the person there? Your work builds from his or hers? He or she has expertise that might suggest improvements? You need to give some reason you are inviting him or her.] Sincerely,[Your name, address, email]
